user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SymbolLookup_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SymbolLookup_Impl(cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32            status;
    int32            local_status;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    /* First search global table */
    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    /* If not found iterate through module local symbols and break if found */
    if (status != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE, &iter);
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            local_status = OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(&iter.token, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);
            if (local_status == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                status = local_status;
                break;
            }
        }
        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SymbolLookup_Impl:
int32 OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(void *dl_handle, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    const char *dlError; /*  Pointer to error string   */
    void *      Function;
    int32       status;

    status = OS_ERROR;

    /*
     * call dlerror() to clear any prior error that might have occurred.
     */
    dlerror();
    Function = dlsym(dl_handle, SymbolName);
    dlError  = dlerror();

    /*
     * For the POSIX DL implementation, if the symbol does not exist
     * then dlerror() is supposed to return non-null.  This is intended
     * to differentiate between valid symbols which are actually 0/NULL
     * and invalid symbols that do not exist.
     *
     * Some implementations do _not_ implement this detail, and dlerror()
     * still returns NULL after looking up an invalid symbol name.
     *
     * In practice, this is expected to be used for looking up functions
     * and as such all valid symbols should be non-NULL, so NULL is considered
     * an error even if the C library doesn't consider this an error.
     */
    if (dlError != NULL)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: %s\n", SymbolName, dlError);
    }
    else if (Function == NULL)
    {
        /* technically not an error per POSIX, but in practice should not happen */
        OS_DEBUG("Error: %s: dlsym() returned NULL\n", SymbolName);
    }
    else
    {
        status = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    *SymbolAddress = (cpuaddr)Function;

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, cpuaddr *SymbolAddress, const char *SymbolName)
{
    int32                             status;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    status = OS_GenericSymbolLookup_Impl(impl->dl_handle, SymbolAddress, SymbolName);

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(osal_objtype_t objtype, OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectFilterActive, NULL, objtype, iter);
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE NULL
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE 0x0A
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I focused on fragments that could be logically or implementation-wise unreachable and therefore should be investigated for compliance with MISRA C Rule 2.1. The other code in the provided snippets was not flagged because it is simple, obviously reachable, or does not present a static unreachable-code concern:

- Simple returns and assignments (e.g. 'return status;', 'status = OS_ERROR;', the inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken) are basic operations and not inherently unreachable.
- The wrapper functions OS_ModuleSymbolLookup_Impl and OS_ObjectIdIterateActive merely call other functions and return their results; they do not contain internal branches that look statically dead.
- The iterator implementation OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext implements a standard search loop whose control flow (increment, boundary check, match check, return of got_next) is reachable depending on iterator state; there is no code after a guaranteed return or other construct that would make parts of it permanently unreachable.
- Macro and constant definitions (OS_SUCCESS, OSAL_DLSYM_DEFAULT_HANDLE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE) are declarations/defines and not executable code that could be unreachable.

The listed fragments were selected because they contain conditional blocks or sequences that, depending on platform/library behavior (e.g. dlerror/dlsym semantics, use of a NULL default handle) or initialization status of the iterator, could be effectively never executed in some builds or environments and therefore warrant investigation for unreachable-code violations.
